text: Generated strong earnings
Grew clients and accounts organically
Seventh consecutive quarter of operating leverage
Strengthened balance sheet
Maintained strong liquidity
Delivered good returns
Comparisons to 1Q22, unless otherwise noted.
Net income of $8.2B; diluted earnings per share of $0.94; ROE 12.5%, ROTCE 17.4%.
Revenue, net of interest expense, of $26.3B increased $3.0B, or 13%.
Net interest income (NII) of $14.4B ($14.6B FTE) increased $2.9B, or 25%, driven primarily by benefits from higher interest rates and solid loan growth.
Noninterest income of $11.8B increased $154MM, or 1%, as higher sales and trading revenue more than offset lower service charges and declines in asset management and investment banking fees.
Provision for credit losses of $931MM.
Net reserve build of $124MM vs. net reserve release of $362MM in 1Q22; build of $403MM in 4Q22.
Net charge-offs (NCOs) of $807MM increased compared to 1Q22 and 4Q22 and remained below pre-pandemic levels.
Net charge-off ratio of 32 bps increased 16 bps vs. 1Q22 and 6 bps vs. 4Q22.
Noninterest expense of $16.2B increased $0.9B, or 6%, vs. 1Q22.
Generated operating leverage for the seventh consecutive quarter (705 bps in 1Q23).
Balance sheet remained strong.
Average loans and leases grew $2B from 4Q22.
Average deposits decreased $32B from 4Q22.
Common Equity Tier 1 ratio of 11.4% increased 14 bps from 4Q22.
Average Global Liquidity Sources of $854B; ending Global Liquidity Sources of $904B.
Paid $1.8B in common dividends and repurchased $2.2B of common stock, including repurchases to offset shares awarded under equity-based compensation plans.
CET1 ratio of 11.4% increased 14 bps vs. 4Q22.
CET1 capital of $184B rose $4B from 4Q22, driven by net income and OCI on AFS debt securities, partially offset by capital distributions to common shareholders.
Standardized RWA of $1,623B increased $19B from 4Q22.
Book value per share of $31.58 improved 3% from 4Q22.
Average Global Liquidity Sources of $854B decreased $14B, or 2%, from 4Q22.
Ending Global Liquidity Sources of $904B.
Bank of America Ranked #1 in U.S. Retail Deposit Market Share
Consumer & Small Business balances from very engaged clients: 85% from clients with more than one product, 85% from clients with everyday transactions, 78% from digitally active clients.
Consumer & Small Business long-tenured relationships: 83% of balances from clients with 5+ year tenure, 67% from clients with 10+ year tenure.
Consumer & Small Business has a diversified business presence in 83 of top 100 markets in the US.
Small Business balances distributed among 17 primary industry types, with none representing >18% of total balances.
Consumer & Small Business 1Q23 rate paid on deposits was 12 bps, up 6 bps from 4Q22.
Global Banking has long-tenured, multi-product relationships: 80% of US balances are held by clients with an account tenure of 10+ years.
73% of Global Banking balances from clients with 5+ total solutions per relationship.
Global Banking client balances are geographically diversified across the US.
Global Banking 1Q23 rate paid on deposits was 170bps, up 57 bps from 4Q22.
Global Wealth & Investment Management has long-tenured and engaged relationships with an average tenure of 14 years.
74% of GWIM banking clients are digitally active, and 74% of checking clients are enrolled in Preferred Rewards.
GWIM 1Q23 rate paid on deposits was 197 bps, up 60 bps from 4Q22.
Managed within various interest rate sensitivity, liquidity, and capital limits.
Deposits in excess of loans grew from $0.5T in 4Q19 to $1.1T (4Q21-1Q22) and were $0.9T at March 31, 2023.
Stored excess deposits in cash and investment securities.
Hedged AFS securities with floating rate swaps, beginning in 2020.
Stopped adding to HTM securities book as deposits appeared to be peaking; book has declined quarterly and is $59B below peak of $683B in 3Q21.
Weighted average life of HTM portfolio currently 8.5 years; AFS 5.5 years.
NII excluding Global Markets trough of $9.1B in 3Q20 vs. $14.5B in 1Q23.
Reduced AFS securities and increased cash in 1Q23.
Net interest income of $14.4B ($14.6B FTE) increased $2.9B YoY, driven by benefits from higher interest rates and loan growth.
Decreased $0.2B from 4Q22, as the benefit from higher interest rates was more than offset by lower deposit balances, two fewer interest accrual days, and lower NII related to GM activity.
NII related to GM activity declined approximately $0.9B YoY, and $0.3B from 4Q22, and was offset in noninterest income.
Premium amortization expense of $34MM in 1Q23, $210MM in 4Q22, and $905MM in 1Q22.
Net interest yield of 2.20% increased 51 bps YoY and decreased 2 bps from 4Q22.
Excluding GM, net interest yield of 2.85%; up 86 bps YoY.
As of March 31, 2023, a +100 bps parallel shift in the interest rate yield curve is estimated to benefit net interest income by $3.3B over the next 12 months.

Noninterest expense of $16.2B in 1Q23 increased $0.7B, or 4%, vs. 4Q22, driven primarily by seasonally higher payroll taxes, continued investments in people and technology, and higher FDIC expense from the 2022 increased assessment on banks.

1Q23 expense increased $0.9B, or 6%, vs. 1Q22, driven by investments in the franchise across people and technology as well as higher FDIC expense, partially offset by lower revenue-related incentive compensation.
Total net charge-offs of $807MM increased $118MM from 4Q22.
Consumer net charge-offs of $653MM increased $122MM, driven primarily by higher credit card losses. Credit card loss rate was 2.21% in 1Q23, up from 1.71% in 4Q22.
Commercial net charge-offs of $154MM decreased $4MM.
Net charge-off ratio of 0.32% increased 6 bps from 4Q22 and remained below pre-pandemic levels.
Provision for credit losses of $931MM.
Net reserve build of $124MM in 1Q23, driven primarily by Consumer due to higher-than-expected credit card balances.
Allowance for loan and lease losses of $12.5B represented 1.20% of total loans and leases.
Total allowance of $14.0B included $1.4B for unfunded commitments.
Nonperforming loans (NPLs) increased $0.1B from 4Q22 to $3.9B, with 60% of Consumer NPLs being contractually current.
Commercial reservable criticized utilized exposure of $19.8B increased $0.5B from 4Q22.
Consumer Banking: Added ~130,000 net new checking accounts; 17th consecutive quarter of growth.
Consumer Banking: Added 1.3 million credit card accounts.
Consumer Banking: Record 3.6 million consumer investment accounts, with $37 billion net client flows since 1Q22.
Consumer Banking: Grew digital sales 4% YoY to 1.8 million; digital sales represented 51% of total sales.
Global Wealth & Investment Management: Added record ~14,500 net new relationships across Merrill and Private Bank.
Global Wealth & Investment Management: $80 billion total net client flows since 1Q22.
Global Wealth & Investment Management: Opened record ~35,000 bank accounts, up 18% YoY.
Global Wealth & Investment Management: Sent ~40,000 referrals to other lines of business.
Global Banking: Grew average loans and leases 6% YoY to $381 billion.
Global Banking: Second best revenue quarter at $6.2 billion, up 19% YoY.
Global Banking: $3.1 billion Global Transaction Services revenue, up 47% YoY.
Global Banking: #3 in investment banking fees.
Global Markets: Grew sales and trading revenue to $5.1 billion.
Global Markets: Second highest quarterly sales and trading revenue in a decade.
Global Markets: Highest quarterly FICC revenue in a decade, up 27% YoY.
Global Markets: Average loans of $125 billion, up 15% YoY.
There was a break in the operating leverage streak from 3Q19 to 2Q21.
Net income of $3.1B increased 4% from 1Q22, driven by strong revenue growth and continued investments in the business.
Pretax, pre-provision income of $5.2B increased 34% from 1Q22.
8th consecutive quarter of operating leverage; efficiency ratio improved YoY to 51%.

Revenue of $10.7B improved 21% from 1Q22, due to increased NII driven by higher interest rates and loan balances, partially offset by the impact of reduced customer non-sufficient funds and overdraft fees.
Provision for credit losses of $1.1B vs. a benefit of $52MM in 1Q22.
Net reserve build of $360MM, driven primarily by higher-than-expected credit card balances.
Net charge-offs of $729MM increased $313MM driven primarily by credit card.
Noninterest expense of $5.5B increased 11% from 1Q22, driven primarily by continued investments in people and technology.
Average deposits remained above $1T and decreased $30B, or 3%, from 1Q22.
57% of deposits in checking accounts; 92% primary accounts.
Average loans and leases of $304B increased $20B, or 7%, from 1Q22.
Combined credit / debit card spend of $210B increased 6% from 1Q22, with both credit and debit up 6%.
Consumer investment assets of $355B declined $3B, or 1%, from 1Q22, driven by lower market valuations, partially offset by record $37B of client flows from new and existing clients.
Record 3.6MM consumer investment accounts, up 9%.
10.3MM Total clients enrolled in Preferred Rewards, up 8% from 1Q22; 99% annualized retention rate.
Net income of $0.9B decreased 19% from 1Q22.
Pretax, pre-provision income of $1.2B decreased 15% from 1Q22.
Pretax margin of 23%.
Revenue of $5.3B decreased 3% compared to 1Q22, driven by the impact of lower equity and fixed income market valuations on asset management fees, partially offset by higher NII.
Noninterest expense of $4.1B increased 1% vs. 1Q22, as investments in the business, including strategic hiring and technology, were mostly offset by lower revenue-related incentives.
Client balances of $3.5T decreased 5% from 1Q22, driven by lower market valuations, partially offset by net client flows.
AUM flows of $15B in 1Q23.
Average deposits of $314B decreased $71B, or 18%, from 1Q22.
Average loans and leases of $221B increased $11B, or 5%, from 1Q22, driven by residential mortgage and custom lending.
Added a record ~14,500 net new relationships across Merrill and Private Bank in 1Q23.
84% of GWIM households / relationships are digitally active across the enterprise, up from 81% in 1Q22.
Net income of $2.6B increased 48% from 1Q22.
Pretax, pre-provision income of $3.3B increased 30% from 1Q22.
Revenue of $6.2B increased 19% vs. 1Q22, driven primarily by higher NII from the benefit of higher interest rates, partially offset by lower investment banking fees and other factors.
Total Corporation investment banking fees (excl. self-led) of $1.2B decreased $0.3B, or 20%, from 1Q22.
Provision for credit losses reflected a benefit of $237MM, driven primarily by an improved macroeconomic outlook, and decreased $402MM from 1Q22.
Noninterest expense of $2.9B increased 10% from 1Q22, primarily reflecting continued investments in the business, including strategic hiring in 2022.
Average deposits of $493B decreased $47B, or 9%, from 1Q22.
Average loans and leases of $381B increased $22B, or 6%, from 1Q22.
Net income of $1.7B increased 6% from 1Q22.
Excluding net DVA, net income of $1.7B increased 9%.
Revenue of $5.6B increased 6% from 1Q22, driven primarily by higher sales and trading revenue, partially offset by lower investment banking fees.
Sales and trading revenue of $5.1B increased 7% from 1Q22.
FICC revenue increased 27% to $3.4B, driven primarily by improved performance across mortgage, credit, municipal products, and increased secured financing activity for clients.
Equities revenue decreased 19% to $1.6B, driven by weaker trading performance and lower client activity in derivatives and cash.
Excluding net DVA, sales and trading revenue of $5.1B increased 9% from 1Q22.
FICC revenue of $3.4B increased 29%.
Equities revenue of $1.6B decreased 19%.
Noninterest expense of $3.4B increased 8% vs. 1Q22, driven by investments in the business, including people and technology.
Average VaR of $109MM in 1Q23.
Net loss of $107MM included a $220MM pretax loss on sale of AFS debt securities.
Total corporate effective tax rate (ETR) for the quarter was 10%, which included certain discrete tax benefits.
Excluding these discrete tax benefits and recurring ESG tax credit benefits, the ETR would have been approximately 26%.
Business Leadership: No. 1 in estimated U.S. Retail Deposits, Online Banking and Mobile Banking Functionality, and Small Business Lender.
Recognized as Best Bank in the U.S., Best Consumer Digital Bank in the U.S., and Best Bank in the U.S. for Small and Medium Enterprises.
Certified by J.D. Power for Outstanding Client satisfaction with Customer Financial Health Support â€“ Banking & Payments.
Business Leadership: No. 1 on Forbes' Best-in-State Wealth Advisors, Barron's Top 100 Women Financial Advisors, and Financial Planning's 'Top 40 Advisors Under 40'.
Received awards for client experience and digital innovation from Celent, MMI/Barron's, and Aite-Novarica.
Recognized as No. 1 in personal trust AUM and Best Private Bank in the U.S. by Family Wealth Report and Global Private Banking.
Acknowledged for Best Philanthropy Offering by WealthBriefing, PWM, and Global Finance.
Business Leadership: Recognized as Global Most Innovative Financial Institution (2022) and World's Best Bank.
Awarded Best Bank for Payment & Collections in North America and received a Model Bank award for Product Innovation in Cash Management.
Named World's Best Bank for Payments and Treasury and received Quality, Share and Excellence Awards for U.S. Large Corporate Banking.
Maintains relationships with 73% of the Global Fortune 500 and 95% of the U.S. Fortune 1,000.
Business Leadership: Awarded Americas Derivatives House of the Year and Americas House of the Year for various derivative categories.
Recognized as Commodity Derivatives House, Americas ESG Financing House, and Interest Rate Derivatives House of the Year.
Named Global Leader for Sustainable Project Finance and Most Sustainable Banks in North America.
Acknowledged as Most Impressive Corporate Bond House in Dollars, No. 1 All-America Sales Team in Equities Idea Generation, No. 1 Municipal Bonds Underwriter, and No. 2 Global Research Firm.
Office portfolio characteristics: ~75% Class A property type, ~55% origination LTV, ~2% NPL to loans, $3.7B reservable criticized exposure, and NCOs of $15MM in 1Q23.
A: Definition of Global Liquidity Sources (GLS).
B: Definition of Reserve Build (or Release).
C: Definition and reconciliation of Pretax, pre-provision income (PTPI), a non-GAAP measure.
D: Assumptions for interest rate sensitivity analysis.
E: Details on net debit valuation adjustments (DVA) on derivatives.
F: Details on the VaR model methodology.
(A) Estimated U.S. retail deposits based on June 30, 2022 FDIC deposit data.
(B) Javelin 2022 Online and Mobile Banking Scorecards.
(C) FDIC, 4Q22.
(D) Global Finance, May 2022.
(E) Global Finance, August 2022.
(F) Global Finance, December 2022.
(G) J.D. Power 2023 Financial Health Support Certification is based on exceeding customer experience benchmarks using client surveys and a best practices verification.
(H) Industry Q4-22 FDIC call reports.
(I) Family Wealth Report, 2022.
(J) Global Private Banking, The Digital Banker, 2022.
(K) WealthBriefing, 2022.
(M) Global Finance, 2022.
(N) Euromoney, 2022.
(O) Global Finance Treasury & Cash Management Awards, 2023.
(P) Celent, 2023.
(Q) Greenwich, 2023.
(R) GlobalCapital, 2022.
(T) Risk.net, 2022.
(U) Capital Monitor, 2022.
(V) Institutional Investor, 2022.
(W) Refinitiv, 2023 YTD.

Actual outcomes may differ materially from those expressed in forward-looking statements.
Readers should not place undue reliance on these statements and should consider the risks and uncertainties discussed in the Corporation's SEC filings.
Key risks include litigation, regulatory actions, interest rate and economic impacts, credit losses, capital and liquidity requirements, geopolitical instability, and operational failures.
The Corporation undertakes no obligation to update any forward-looking statement.
The information is preliminary and based on data available at the time of the presentation, speaking only as of the dates included.
The presentation may contain non-GAAP financial measures; reconciliations and more information are available in the earnings press release.
The Corporation presents key financial and nonfinancial performance indicators that management uses to assess performance.
Net interest income is also viewed on a fully taxable-equivalent (FTE) basis, a non-GAAP measure, for comparative purposes.
Capital is allocated to business segments based on a methodology considering regulatory requirements and internal risk-based models, which was adjusted in 1Q23.
